Bibliographic details for the Source Text Robert Armin, fl. 1610 (1565?-1610)The History of the two Maids of More-clacke, VVith the life and simple maner of Iohn in the Hospitall. Played by the Children of the Kings Maiesties Reuels. VVritten by Robert Armin London Printed by N. O. for Thomas Archer [etc.]1609 [70] p. Preliminaries and introductory matter omitted.
Play details
The two maids of More-Clacke. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1609. Date first performed: 1606. THE History of the two Maids of More-clacke, VVith the life and simple maner ofIohnin the Hospitall.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Madge Sir William Vergir Sir Rafe Sir Robert tours Earl of Tumult Filbon Auditor Humil Tutch, the Clown James John Lady Mistress Mary Nurse Boy Lord Messenger Henry, the Priest Servant Mistress Tabitha Governor Ferris, waterman Watt, waterman Combined speech Maid Serving Man Gentleman Lord 1 Lord 2 Mr./Sailor Unknown voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.stage: Enter a maide strowing flowers, and a seruing man perfuming the doore.

sp.speaker: Maide.
sp.p: Strew, Strew.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The Muscadine stays for the bride at Church, The Priest and himens ceremonies tend To make them man and wife.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: By my maiden-head a joyful time, I will pave their Way with flowers.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: While I perfume.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Some say this widow is rich.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I will not say as poor as Iob, but as bare as January, when the trees look like a girl, whose colour comes and goes as frost does in the milk,

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: It was wont to be a rich widow and a poor knight, but now false, a knight rich and the widow poor.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How ever honour is most rich, no matter who is poor.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I would my fortune were no worse

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thine may be better.

sp.speaker: Maid.
Hum.
sp.p: What are the waits of London come?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Play in their highest key then. hautboys play.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: sound Hautboys.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Make the Gods dance, cause Jovial mirth
Music in heaven for this earths marriage
Is a triumphant concord to us all,
To me it is sealed by promise for his daughter,
Who in our blood shall sympathise, says I,
She shall be ours, bedded, although some
Menace a rivalship, yet the sure card
Gives the trick ours, and we shall win,
Since in my mother it doth first begin.

div1.stage: Enter the solemne shewe of the marriage, Sir William Vergir, Earle, Lords, Auditor, SirRafe, Sir Robert Toures, Filbon, others. Enter Lady, mistres Mary, mistres Tabitha, and some other women for shewe. After all. Enter Iames a citizen, father to Humil.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: A good one to thyself, to us it is seasoned,

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: A marriage sir?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Aye and a good one friend.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Because it is rich.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Good reach at stars, in faith it is true.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: In whom sir, if I may be bold.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: A knight of More-clack to a London widow.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: My burdened soul says I, a Knight of More-clack to the widow Humil, just, it is she,

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: By this the blessing of the holy rights,
Relishes in them, they are married, at least
Fair for it, I must witness to it, fare-well.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: How ignorance pleads nonage, in his eye
He knows me not, it is not the Lions kind,
Whose nature challenges right property,
Of perfect being, if it were,
Humil would Humill know, that him begot,
To be what now he is married again,
And her first husband living, blame her not,
It is my own project, thank my letters,
That falsified our deaths black funeral,
Into her mournful hearing, follow it,
Think on thy soul, divide that bitter band,
Knit by the closure of a mutual hand.

div1.stage: exit. Enter two watermen with luggedge.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I rest ye sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: At whose suit Wat?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: At the bridegrooms, I will not a foot further till I have eased my shoulders.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: No nor I, we are asses right, we carry provender, but are not the better for it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Thou wilt not believe breads bread, till it be tasted, I say to thee, in this trunk is provender.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: be an ass till thou prove it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Here is money which will buy it.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: O by a figure, I say to thee thou art an ass. How?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: By thy burthen.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: No otherwise, that is not so good.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Because thou hast ears.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Are all asses that have ears?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Are all trunks laden with money that are heavy?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: indeed I confess in that I am an ass, but I think so.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
By such a surmise thou makest it provender.
We are water-men, and think because we see a man coming, and that I am his first man, he will be my first fare, when another gets him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Come, you are bookish.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And thou blockish, say rights right, and no more.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Se sirrah Mr. Tutch, what an officer?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, he is booking in, Mr. Tutch, salve, sis salve.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Iubio te saluere, aue.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: He hears us not.

sp.speaker: Tuch.
sp.p: Let me see Capons, Turkeys, Small-birds, Beefs, Muttons, Partridge, Plover, Wood cocks.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Meaning us, good morning, and many sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: And many Mr.Tutch.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Are ye come water-squirts, are ye come?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: And why sir, water-squirts?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Because you shoot water, and so do they, but have ye that will do it, my dainty element dashers.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Do it and stand to it Mr.Tutch if we might spend it sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Well said honest knaves, bear in, but say where is Iohn in the the hospitall, and his nurse?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: At hand sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: It is well, away, and Tutch tutch the tips of their tongues, with our seller suckets.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I will tutch the tips of their tongues, and their tongues tips, I will baste their bellies and their lips till we have jerked the cat with our three whips.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Married? it is ended, and the next pull mine. At a fair fleece, a golden one, the eldest daughter is my hope, what then rests in it, O you winged lap-wings, farthest cry, when we come nearest to it. Quando pecus omnia sub umbra ruminat antiquos paulilum vocitamus amores.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: It is done too late to ask why so.
Tardy intrusion as a Cipher plaste.
Fills but up room, while substance in the other
Makes number precious, I am that round O,
Which with a sigh, as sad as is my soul,
Grieve all too late, what now befits my moan,
But black despair, and die in it do,
To make thyself known, but represents
Mellow fruit falling into danger, O I am that
Rotten ruined, and unrelished substance,
Which on my own upgrowing tree falls off,
By the times negligence, undone I am,
Would I had died indeed, and not in word.
These ill tuned words like discords sounded harsh
And yet were thought true music, well, well,
I will take my stand, and as she passes by
Note if her glories dash not all my hopes
With base forgetfulness of what she was,
My picture can she not forget, may be,
Old love may yet live in this new-born Lady.

div1.stage: Enter the solemne order of the Bride-groomes returne from Church, and as the bride goes by, she beholds Iames the cittizen with earnest eye, and speakes aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am wonder stricken in myself,
O you all-seeing, pardon my attempt,
My second choice hath laid siege to my soul,
And my disloyalty hath in that witness
Slain the concurrences of after joy,
Even so he looked that had my maiden heart,
Even such was he, whose far estranged death
Gave me this licence of ill liberty,
To do, and undo, O forgive me then,
Weak in my sect, my fault to the best of men.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: New wedded Lady, and our mornings bride,
What is it that troubles ye?

div1.stage: Lets fal her gloue, Iames takes it up.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: A loss but being small.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: No matter for the loss.
You find a purchase, equals any cross.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let it go then.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: she knows me and this constant accident
Subscribes to it, how can she excuse,
This double deed, this false neglect of love?
O women how you dally in your trust,
How quickly you forget late living life,
And bury the remembrance in your smiles
All ye this morning for the dead to sigh,
And shed your tears in bosom of new choice
How have I sifted your loose difference,
For ever being president against all.
Glad am I at this opportunity,
Who landed me even in the jaws of fear
Swallowing my destiue happiness
To utter ruin of herself and me
If the unconstant air whistle abroad,
That Humill lives, then Humils widow dies
In desperate scandal, racked and tormented,
In the remembrance of old wretchedness,
Which to prevent, plots cunningly contrived
Must buckler my repute so weakly wived.

div1.stage: exit Enter sir Robert Toures, and yong Filbon.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Lost her glove?
So she makes known.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: I will find it to my ever-living glory,
And the next triumph, wear it in my helm
Daring all gallants in defence to approve,
Sir William Vergirs Lady owes this glove.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: If my good fortune challenge such account,
To find it by my friend or industry,
I will prick it on a pole, and with my lance,
Curvet with nimble speed, in course of arms,
And as I snatch it by a curious pass,
Cry in loud echo, here is for her love,
Who on her wedding day did loose this glove.

div1.stage: exit. Enter the two maiden sisters, Mary and Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: The Bride, our new made mother lost her glove.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: Aye sister, so she says.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I will seek no further, for it is in vain.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Especially when quicker eyes than ours,
Arch in the brows of loves two votaries,
Lord how they will brag to find it questionless,
It will prove a ransom of a thousand kisses,
Amorous glances, modest courtesy,
O how these flatterers can insinuate,
And stretch an inch of length to an ell of wide
Here is much in office for a little pay.
A glove God wot.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye sister, so they say, go to ye wanton you
He that shall marry thee, is matched in faith,
To English rash, or to a Dutch snap-haunce,
You will strike fire with words---

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: Who I? now as I live sweet Moll.
If Filbon marry me, as by this light.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: And wink.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: It is hard to juggle with the devil, we maids
So simper in each others quantity
As we know fashion ere it be deuized
Forswear you one, and I will forsweare---

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: The other, just even so,
Shall I be plain with thee---

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.p: You will answer, no

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: No I.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I no.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: I know you will not, therefore let him go,
I love my Filbon as men love good clothes,
Put them on every day.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And I love Toures as I love my sleep,
Embracing thus, folding most dearly.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: Your lover nightly, as you wish him yearly.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: In troth in such a sort:

sp.speaker: Tabith,
sp.p: As children play with stones, to make them sport.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: You make me blush Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: At the thing ye wish,
Plague on the cat that loves nor milk nor fish.
We are all maidens pictures, fain we would,
Yet we cry away away, when away we should.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yet again.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.p: Never yet. Ever so when so our matters fit.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: They are returned, a glove or no.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: No, but the glove I sought not, I have found.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Where is it man?

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: You are the glove, which still I seek to wear
Make me happy, match it to a pair.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Be these for ever matches.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: How can ye find the glove was never lost?

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: By seeking you that lost not what we find.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: Indeed a willing loss, is loss of gain,
Where loving finders pity losers pain,
I will not say, enjoy so much the rather,
Because gift giver cries out on the father.
But if I durst, I would, till when.
Unmatch our gloves, each take his own again.

div1.stage: Enter Sir William, Iames, Earle of Tumult, Auditor, sir Rafe.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: It is enacted by the brides fair word,
Who finds her glove, is this days governor.
To manage all our pastimes in the house,
And thou art he, the only conqueror,
Of prize and honour, then enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: You give and I receive, is this my office?

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.p: Signed and delivered.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I take it on me, music triumphs come,
Since fortune cast her favours in my fist,
I will be most prodigal.
Yet with modesty I am a Citizen.
Unlooked for welcome, and unthinking come,
To receive honour in a states mans room.
Yet to this presence I will still address,
Love, pains and duty in this business.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: In this is fortune blind, whose deeds are dangers,
Giving her graces not to friends but strangers.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Prove on my fortunes how so ere they stand,
I hold my fairest fortune in my hand.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: The like do I.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: And all the fairest fortunes I would prove,
Is only this, to enjoy my dearest love.

sp.speaker: Tabi.
sp.p: The like I wish.

sp.speaker: Humyl.
sp.l: All happiness live in thy choice, in hers
All mischiefs, horror, les ourself participate in tender of
our choice, freely delivered in the sight of heaven.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: What news?

sp.speaker: Humyl.
sp.p: The wedding dinner breaths his last.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: And we will visit it; on forward there.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: So fair and fortunate to be thus false,
Wedded to two. O you all wondering eyes,
Gaze till your fire flame, your eye-balls drop
In moist imagination of this act,
Before the first be dead to wed a second O

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why writ you dead in your last letters?
Sick was I, and no likelihood of life.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: What then, was that a just excuse
To varnish over this base counterfeiting? no,
I will make it known.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I care not, I will thus excuse it,
All opposite of injury was yours,
Putting to test our weakness by your letters,
Which carrying credit, woman in her will,
Guiltless is causer of this open ill.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Had I been thus advised, but all too late
Acquainted with your speed, I had prevented what now is
past and done,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why did you not? Bawd to your own misdeed,
Three quarters guilty of this accident,
That might and would not stop the hazard,
Will ye now heap up miracle,
And make it worse in note, by adding to it
A bauins blaze, it is not so soon extinct,
Being fierce of flame, quenched must it be,
By water-course of sounder policy.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: I am from myself in this, what shall I do?
O I am mad, and mischief menaces unwitting of all purpose.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.l: Why did I cast my glove,
Proclaimed the finder stickler of our sports,
But to a point prevailing practise?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I know not how.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Leave all to me, women that wade in sin,
Have their wits-charter to authorize it,
And they have antidotes that to digest,
Which better judgments lose themselves in, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: To lie with him the while.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.l: It is true to lie with him, but not in sheets,
To use the flourish of a woman's skill,
In winds and turnings, other lying,
My new-made husband injures not the old,
As I am simply false, I will be found
Constant to death, knowing my business
Is to heal up the fractures of the time,
And to salve virtue in her taint of ill.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I build on this.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Some month.
While I, possess the glory of my name,
Attendances according, marry our son
Unto his eldest daughter, that is the point
Of all: regain my jointer next,
It is not amiss to satisfy your debts,
These two achieved, the third as bedding,
And if this brain beguile him not of that,
Say I am single: no, since blame sits nigh,
Behooves give care to use true policy.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Our son.
sp.l: Mother the noble guest expects ye,
The present meeting does neglect itself
Where our fair bride is wanting,
Pray come in, you do them wrong.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am not well, and this commanding air
Retains my health, I came to fetch it,
Wherefore enriched with what was ours before,
We yield fresh duty and attend them.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Will you be mindful of our marriage, mother?
Begin so happily in yours.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I shall endeavour in it, come.

div1.stage: Exeunt. Enter Marie, Tabithe, Toures and Filbon.

sp.speaker: Tabithe.
sp.l: Close and hushed, not a fly stirring,
While they feed hungrily, we, that loves deity
Does proclaim pardon to presume, and speak,
Challenge liberty, now by my maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Swear not love.

sp.speaker: Tabithe.
sp.p: Can you forbid my oath? Sir I will swear, and till I lack it, say, nought shall confine me, I had rather feast in fancies pittance, than to feed gaged with attention, soothing every bit with curiosity: no, I can fill my belly in a minute, satisfy my stomach in a breath: Lovers digest their sighs, and chow their spleen, while other appetites fall hungry to it, and let them greedily graze on.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What is all this?

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Lovers talk anything.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: I understand ye not.

sp.speaker: Tabithe.
sp.p: I would not that you should, for I speak Greek.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Regard her not, for she talks, Idly Filbon.

sp.speaker: Tabi.
sp.l: Be you advised then sister, I am a fool.
Yet not so simple but I talk by rule,
I say, dine they that list, I will not, for my dish
Dressed to my hand is here, here let me feed,
It is the maids modicum, God send us speed.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.l: In that I claim a part,
Who ever feeds this dish hath Maries heart.

sp.speaker: Tabi.
sp.p: So then said I well, ye wicked thing.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Mot as I am of Lovers union,
Contracted to a solitary life,
By thus retaining singleness of heart:
Changing all doubts that the world affords
But one, so to thy sweetest self,
Which only art idea of my thoughts:
I vow a reconciled amity,
Which violated, does command my life
To yield his interest to the shade of death,
May be, your father alienates our choice,
And shows as sunshine threatening rain,
To the all-hoping harvest present,
Which to make clear, the honourable word
And fatherly regard in present office
Have past their speed in our attention.
I know your father will receive their on-set
Soldier-like, joying the siege begun,
Which though resisted, bids them gladly come.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Pause in that trust, give ear.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Sound proclamation,
It is enacted by the bride and bridegroom,
And by ourself chief in authority,
That all receive their pleasures
From the most high in this assembly
To the lowest, all pastimes are made free,
Dancing, carding, dicing revelling.
And other dues of times fit merriment's,
---Vnto the bride and bridegrooms health.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.p: The days short, and the night's

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: Stop there.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.p: I will, to pleasure thee,

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: There take your places.
And in your sweetest key of music strokes
Sound pleasant melody, echo those sounds
Which true-love-hearts, in concords chiefest grounds
Have their blessed being, use art in times,
Which may give welcome to our noblest guests.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: We are betrayed, yong Humill is at hand,
Dance, and excuse it so.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: Sound music there.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Content, a dance, and in again.
Content, no dance, yet in again.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: It is ungently don to snatch her so.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I snatch but that which promise says is mine, Have I offended?

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Right what is wrong.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Here, Or where you dare, go seek in Brainford, go.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Brainford?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Put up, or I shall be offending unto one, Against the brides son, dare ye?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I repent not what is done, come you with me.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: So slaves by violence do hurry hence, The rights of---

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Peace, we on you do impose command.
Yield duty in it: hall, a hall there.
Music sound, and to the bride do consecrate this round.

div1.stage: Enter all the traine to daunce.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Squire of the day, cull out your gadding bucks. Select your light-heeled does, open your Labits, Turn them to the toils; we that are Venus Huntsmen may partake the sports.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: You are a gallant woodman sir.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: My son for one.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe,
sp.p: And mine the other.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Good my daughters for them both, A course or so, go too, lead on, the bucks that have employment for these does, are not these giddy gamesters, I will be the Forester and look to it.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Hear you that?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: A lightning before heat.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: Your fathers air is herald to his tongue.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.p: He knows the coat, but thinks not who shall wear it.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: There is two and two.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: A couple more, two makes no show, our measure is for three.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: Why then the bride.

sp.speaker: S. Kafe.
sp.p: And bridegroom.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: O sir, pardon me. My joints were oiled to pleasure, but now, not.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Then I with her.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: You! O, your authority commands her.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Hark.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: It gives his luster light.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: My warrant wins, where his does loose the right.

div1.stage: Humil snatches Mary from Toures and dances.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: My son in law grows bold.
Good again, here is much to do in love,
One simply stands, not challenging his own:
And reason, Mary, chance is yet unknown
No, nor in you sir, though my son,
Words past contrive, but after deeds cry done.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: Brookest thou this disgrace.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: O sir, no remedy, what Justice lives so free.
And to her own is friending,

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: I am mad to think on it boy, but---

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: How Goddess-like the elder of the two,
Stations the measure, it is a Jovial sight,
Where beauty gilds the pavement with her light.
How sullen Saturne took her by the hand.
With frosty feeling, in whose icy touch,
She shrunk her hold, but with a jealous eye,
She glanced on me, fearful that standers by
Should be enriched with it: now she smiles me fair,
Gilding my torture with an after hope.
Thus moralised, I season on my right,
Her love thus challenged by inferior might.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: After this dalliance here comes other sport.
Pray ye attend him gallants: How now Iohn?
Tardi venientis Iohn, you must be whipped.
Quo so preceptor, non est tibi quid.

div1.stage: Enter Iohn, Nurse, Boy, all in blew coates.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: This silly sot, my Lord, so please you hear him,
Utters much hope of matter, but small gain.
An old wife nursed him, which we call blind Ales.
She dying, left him to the cities keeping.
Which in their Hospitall they thus nursed up
Amongst the bounties of their other deeds:
Many besides, now you shall hear his fellow
Ask him such questions as his simpleness
Answers to any: sirrah let me hear ye.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Iohn, how many parts of speech be there?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Eight, the vocative, and ablative, caret nominatiuo O,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What say you to reddish Iacke?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: That it does bite, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Where have you been Iacke?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: At Powles friend.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Who saw you there?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Mr. Deane Nowel, O he is a good man truly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What did he give thee Iack?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: A groat, look here else.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What wilt do with it? Carry it home to my Nurse.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will give thee a point Iack, what wilt do with it?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: carry it home to my nurse.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will give thee a fools head Iack, what wilt do with it?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: carry it home to my nurse,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Carry a fools head, what a fool art thou?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Should I go home without it? who is fool now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Who tolls the bell for Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I know not,

div1.stage: Iohn toles the bell, as if a pul'd the rope.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: When died he?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Even now,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Hoo Iacke hoo,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: My Nurses chicken. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: A silly ignorant, is he ever so?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Never otherwise, a cleanly Idiot, what is put on him in his morning ries, is as you see it. This old woman is his Nurse.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: So please your honour you are sent for to the Court, The Court goes from Richmond to White-hall.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: We will attend her, kind sir William Vergir. Our times bridegroom to yourself and you. We wish as we have ever done, all love, And for our present entertainment rest indebted to your bounty, if a Courts amends have in it power of satisfaction, you command it, this acknowledged ever, your poor acquaintance but an honourable friend.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: We will attend your coach.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Sir, be mindful of our servant Filbon. What wants in him to weigh down love with gold, Our favours shall supply.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: It is a light weight, their portions if they poise no better, will to the worlds belief, grow less not greater, but let them pass, I weigh them as they are. Come Nurse, follow us Iohn.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p:
Wipe your nose, fie a sloven still, look ye be mannerly, hold up your chin, let me see ye make your holiday leg, so my chucking, that is a good lamb, do not cry for
anything, Iohn if ye do.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: No Nurse, grace a God, Grace a Queen.

div1.stage: Enter Sir William and his Ladie.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Shriek no more in my ear, I pre-thee peace, I grant I made such promise: but what then, shall I for that so set her on the rack, when her fair fortunes look a better way, with the small proffer of your giddy son, no: you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: You will let me have my jointer yet.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.p: Yes that, three hundred by the year it is thine, But for your sons to wed my eldest daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, he doth merit her in my accord, and it is no wrong in you, to dip her blood in the self dye that we are in.

sp.speaker: Sir. Wil.
sp.p: I grant his merit, but her shining value made golden glittering, by my vauntings looks to a higher promintoria, from which tower, when your son gazes, it affrights him, yields him planet stroke.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He shall not have her then.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Believe it wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He shall.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I will not bed with you till then.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have said it, and when posture of our word takes his base being, I will die the death, into our wedding sheets shall mischief come, before my body break your word with me, even on your wedding day.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Nay then up with the lists, again it shall not be.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I care not, think you I do, keep your word in that, when I break mine.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: No more, be stranger to my bed, do do. Have I of nothing made thee much and wilt thou---

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Yes I will, have you of protestations, oaths, and vows made these loose fractures: lawful be it then for me to shun the make-peace bed, since strife sets such division
betwixt man and wife, I am most firm in it.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Very well, it is not amiss.

div1.stage: Enter Auditor, sir Ralph, Toures, Filbon, and their sonnes.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: The night draws on, it is time to part.

sp.speaker: Sir. Wil.
sp.p: At your pleasures gentlemen.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: Your gallant daughters will be next.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Or not at all, for I am past it now.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: And we are paid unto, our sons are gentlemen, what resteth then, but we sail nearer to the point?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: What point?

sp.speaker: S. Ra.
sp.p: Of marriage past, betwixt us in our promises.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Indeed to one I promised her weight in gold, unto the other which I love as dear, her weight in silver, now gentlemen what goods have you to equal these large promises?

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: Why all we have.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: But it will not serve,
The big avouchments of my promises
Controls you all, and all mens else, ye all,
Under degrees of Earls, Lords, or as Potent
To toll them on I echo these large sums.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Unvalued must your sums be to such choice,
Honour looks high above such petty price.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Look honour high as heaven,
Our earthly reach doth level in that eye,
And with the embellishment of richer worth
I will by, and out-by the imprisoned scope,
Of reaching blood, what will not value do
Where strong ability does reach his hand,
And they have beauty too, which joined to riches
Will proffer fair: though not so quaint
As courtly dames or earths bright treading stars,
They are maids of More-clacke, homely milke-bole things,
Such as I love and fain would marry well.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: It was a promise in you to be kind.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p:
I will forward with that promise, you love
my eldest.---

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: With my soul.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: And pity to divide that love, then hearken me, when she is dead and lives again, she is yours, not till then.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Then never but in death.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: You love my youngest daughter.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: And will ever.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Pray ye do: but when you are from yourself a woman, she is yours in marriage.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Woman to woman joined it were wonderful, but in more maze of wonder I should be, what I do challenge to participate, and from myself live to divide in other.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Faith not till such a wonder.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Is it not enough to scandal thy true word?
But are we slighted thus with fantasies,
Impossibilities, dead and alive again,
Manhood infused in woman: it is not generous.

sp.speaker: Audi.
sp.l: Come son upon my blessing
Take from thy eyes thy heart adoring shine,
Offer no more thy altar bearing thoughts
To one so giant-like, whose reach sits hie,
Above the compass of a gentle eye.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: you have your answers, gallants.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: We like it not.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: Nor will we so except it.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Forewarned come near my house,
Rapes, felonies, and what may else be thought on,
I will with heavy impositions
Surcharge ye with, if not with pistol shot,
I will defend myself and these I keep.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Live I to hear this?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: Convey them from him, let us.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: In disguise.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Or not at all.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: That way or none.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Iames, when I put thee from my thought, let me be hoodwinked from all, fortune, thy partaking gentleness is such, as I do love thee, troth I do.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: God continue this good league.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Wot'st what news?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: The lovers are expulsed, and my fair hopes shine the clearer: what wilt say when I do marry this Knights eldest daughter?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: That you are then possessed.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: She is mine contracted in her fathers word.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: New broken sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: It is true your mother challenged it: but he as angry as the raging morn, whose choler breathing shakes high battlements, puts her off with a pause of contrary, I know it sir, her jointer is subscribed too, which else to do, sooner should earth to heaven presume a progress, than the grant make firm what the antecedent challenges, your mother upon this abandons from his bed, vowing bold absence, he enraged, gives way to all malign and stubborn fashion of contempt, such a close today never had practise, such a wedding night, till this sad first never had purchase: you shall well agree them sir, to atone this jar, use means I pray you, it will become ye, well, when wrangling wrestles with such violent injury, it is the sons office.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: It is the devils office and not mine, to hell obedience, if he break his word.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: You had a father loved ye better.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: He loud me as a king in a play, his servant who were seeing him gives kind applause, but small utility: my father in my child-hood loud and left me to the worlds eye, in bold necessity, I thank him for it, since he died my mother hath her chance, mine wants the proof, stand by times minion and inconstancy, O.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Have patience.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Yes, whereunto? sith all my hopes lie level
With despair, such milk-sops in whose breasts,
Lingers a lagging hope, to the is patience separable;
But to me, horror, and hells black motions tickles
Me on to mischief, and I will---

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: So.
Now swims upon the maine, such shipwrecked-souls,
As the winds rage splits on the rocks of danger.
I, my wife, and son all three, now heave, and
Fear of sinking, makes us timorous.
Should we be shelving on the shallow beach,
The seas rough gusts might scatter our intents,
So idle purchase might be gathered up,
from our so sudden shipwreck: No my state
Stands yet secure: though maimed yet is not foiled:
But salved by wise occasion may make good
This sudden overflow of tide and flood.

div1.stage: Exit. Enter Iohn i'th hospitall, and a blew-coat boy with him.

sp.speaker: Boy., Iohn.
sp.p: Where hadst this bread and butter?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: The crow did give it me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But take heed the kite take it not from thee.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I will choke first.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Iohn shall us play at counter-hole in the cloister?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I have never a counter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will give thee one for a point.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Do, and I will play hose go down, O sir, Willy is a good man truly, here is good custard and capon, and good bread and butter too.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now Iohn, I will cry first.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: And I will cry lag. I was in hobbles hole.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I have won this Iohn, now for another.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I will have it again will I will O.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p:
What is the matter, making my sweet lamb cry?
Come Iohn we must to London, on with your clean muckender, and take leave of sir William and his Lady. Gods me your point, where is it Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: The crow has it, and did win it at counter hole.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: I will whip ye for it, take him up, loose your point lamb, fie, up with him sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Good Nurse now, no more truly O, O

sp.speaker: Ferris.
sp.p: Where is this suck-egg, wheres lack a boy: Come ye moveable matron, wheres this tugegge, away, away.

sp.speaker: Nurs,
sp.p: I will take leave of Sir William and go away.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Now my Iohn juggler, your nose is like Lothbery conduit, that always runs waste.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What is his name Iohn? Sternigogilus, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A goggle eye, a wanton eye, a madcap, so he means.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Wat?

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Hollo.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Trim boat, turn head, we are at hand muschrumpe, We come boy, we come.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Come Iohn, our leave is taken.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Have over the sea to florida, and was not good King Salomon, Tom Tyler.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O well sung Nightingale, a board a board there, ha rip there.

div1.stage: Enter Toures in a tawny coate like a tinker, and his boy with budget and staffe, Toures tincks vpon his pan drinking.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Boy, you understand me, though the liquor have rinsed me, remember your business boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes master.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: It is rare to be a tinker boy, work enough, wench enough, and drink enough, is it not boy?
Aye Master.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Boy where shall us have doings, I will clout any woman's cauldron, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master, think on it is time, for we have never a penny.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Pawn budget boy, I will ring in boy, have any work for a tinker, ati, ti, tinker.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: By my maiden-head it is he, the merry tinker of Twitnam boy, is it not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes flower in the frying pan, he stops holes well it is he,

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Has his old songs still, has he not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, and new to boot.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p:
And be not these tinkers knaves? upon their backs they bear a long pick, with a staff in the end,
He shall have work, I will break way for him, and Call out the gentlewoman to hear him sing.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Let them all say what they can dainty come thou to me. We shall have work master.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Draw boy, homo armatus, boy, I will pepper your pans, Where is my dog boy?

div1.stage: Enter S.William Humil, Lady Mary, Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: your Dame has him, and will meet you at Putney.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Indeed what is a tinker without his wench, staff and dog.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is this the tinker you talk on?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Aye madam of Twitnam, I have seen him lick out burning fire brands with his tongue, drink two pence from the bottom of a full pottle of ale, fight with a Masty, and stroke his moustaches with his bloody bit fist, and sing as merrily as the soberest Chorister.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Come tinker, stop, mend.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: I will tickle your holes.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: He is out of tune for singing now.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Out of tune and temper too, thus can dainty liquor do. Sing boy.

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.p: Relish master, relish, a note above et amaister, Sol. fa, me, re.

sp.l: A maiden sitting all alone,
Unto herself she made great moan,
Sorrow set upon her cheek,
And she looked green as any leek:
Her friends did ask her cause of care;
But she cried out in her despair.
O stone, stone ne ra, stone na ne ra, stone.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.p: Cold comfort in a stone.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Doctors came her pulse to feel,
And Surgeons with their tools of steel,
To dig, to delve, to find her pain,
But all they did it was in vain,
Still on her back this maiden lies,
And with an open throat she cries.
O stone, stone na ne ra, stone ne na ne ra stone.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.p: Better and better by my slipper.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Old wives they made answer thus,
Green sickness was most dangerous.
And oatmeal eating is a food,
That never yet did maiden good.
Tut, tut, tut, it is nothing so,
Still she cried out with pain and woe.
O stone, stone ne na ne ra, stone ne na ne ra, stone
Till she was delivered of a chopping boy, and all was as I am, Omne bene.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: What a disfiguring diet, drunkenness,
Lays upon man, a beastly appetite.
Lingers the body where such glutinous means,
Swelters in surfeit of desire and ease.
I am an enemy to myself, to think,
That man is slave so to continual drink.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Knight, feast, knight, a good cellar keeper knight.
I will cuss thy daughter knight.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Shall us not buss knight, shall us not neb?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Thou art in the straits Moll, and the pirate's shot will sink thee, therefore yield.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: I am thy Toures, being thus disguised, am come to steal thee, then be sudden Moll.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Nay then in faith.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Knight shall us drink at door like beggars? no, I will in knight see thy seller, is thy seller in dept, knight dare he not show his face? your black jacks are my elder brothers, knights, shall us not shake hands with our brothers knight?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Follow him, look he steal nothing.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Tinkers steal nought but drink and maidenheads, I will watch him for one, if you allow loss of the other.

sp.speaker: Sir. Wil.
sp.p: Wheres Tutch?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Who wait you on?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: On the world sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: And what says the world to ye?

div1.stage: Giue her the letter as she talkes.

sp.speaker: Tutch,
sp.p: To me sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: To you sir, what a message? letters, ha, daughter I will be your secretary, nay hide not, juggle not with me, I will once be secret to your thoughts, in faith I will.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: It is a card of lace sir, which he bought me.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Aye bone-lace sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Bone-lace subscribed too like a letter, lace weaved of ten bones, is it so? even so. O Tutch.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: O mistress now am I tried on my own tutch,
I am true metal one way, but counterfeit an other:
O life no life, but mess of public wrong,
Day turn to night, for I have lived too long.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: From Filbon.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Yes from Filbon, woe to the day, time, and hour.

sp.speaker: Tabi.
sp.p: Wherefore.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: That I brought this news from your lover therefore.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Pull off your coat.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I need not sir, it is ready to fall off, yet if I do, it is the time of year, and fall of leaf sir, and serving men do drop their coates, there sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Begone, come no more near my house, if thou do thou art a felon, are you the carrier, are ye indeed, must love make you his mercury, must Filbon send by you? my own betray my own, to him, your a knave, they shuffle ye about, I will deal the cards and cut ye from the deck, you understand me, go.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Gang is the word, and hang is the worst, we are even, I owe you no service, and you owe me no wages, short tale to make, the summers day is long, the winter nights be short, and brickill beds does hide our heads, as spittle fields report.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Wife coop up our ginnie hen, that wants this treading, you gossip, to your closet, Filbon shall, if we want will, yes yes; what else.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come daughter.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: I deem Filbon to his face, bring me to him, I will justify that all his actions are like apricots, they dangle and love them.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: You do.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Alas sir, mistress Marie is with the Tinker gone, and at the back door horsed, I see the gelding, it was a dapple gray.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Hell and damnation.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Death and torture,

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: Christmas gambols, father, shooting the wild mare.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Am I a jest to laugh at now, indeed, indeed.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: O not so fast sir, I am for your race, and will out strip ye, if ye run no faster, speak what was this tinker?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Tinker sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Aye, thy master.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My master is a knight, who Ioue-like in the shape of such a thing, came to see Daunie in this shower of gold.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Toures was it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Etiam, ita, ego I sir.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Now fortune at the fairest, go with thee, thou hast been coming in this stratagem, and I do give thee joy with all my heart.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: You do housewife.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Wishing a whirlwind in the like disguise.
Fetch me hence smoothly, I am lawful price.

sp.speaker: Sir. Wil.
sp.p: Wheres Iames?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: At London.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I will thither too, since the devil drives I am the second, lock her up, safe be it your charge.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: What for this counsellor, concealing rape and ruin of your child?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Whip him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I shall never endure it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Unless you do betray this trust, and tell us to what cabinet he hath conducted her.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To Putney, O to Putney sir, where they will be be married.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: At my parsonage, God amen, no other hospitall to shadow them but mine, am I the patron of so hard mischance, that my own of my own shall cousin me, I will thither, son your company?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: No, I will to Richmond sir, prevent them there.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: No sir, you shall with me, that is the next office, for yourself, delaying due, in other all things ready, you will then serve yourself, nor he nor you shall carve so to your appetites.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: For my sake turned away.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Yes, my master turns a new leaf, and so must I sir, it was for your letters sake.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Is there no hope?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: What do you call it when the ball sir hits the stool?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Why out.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Even so am I, out, out of all hope ever to come in to crumb my porridge at his rabble sir.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Welcome to mine, then honest Tutch, but speak thy mind, thinkest thou she will continue firm?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Firm sir, yes, unless you take her for a join stool. she will continue firm, she feeds on ye, dreams on ye, hopes on ye, and relies on ye, telling her father what a friend you are, protesting and molesting to the hole house of your good parts, vowing to God and man if she have not you, she will have nothing: for any mans pleasure, she will not live if not for yours.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: I stand resolved.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: She wishes that ye should, or she will not trust to ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Rafe.
sp.p: Son seest thou yong Toures?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Not since our last repulse in love, since when I stand affected unto singleness of life.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: Then art thou stable in my thoughts, but let me whisper to thee boy, young Toures in a Tinkers habit hath her stolen, to whom his hearty adoration's were to this hour consecrate, she is gone, and her old doting father got to complain him at the court, how it will work I know not.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Like wax, she will take any impression, sir she.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Like a think say ye?

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: Certainly even so.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: It was my own project father, he applauded it, knowing my fashion of that counterfeit, to be so sure, as no man could forgo me.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: But himself sir, it is a point of law, arraign him upon Ipse facto.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: And art thou slept beyond me? where tonight thou sleep'st: soft be thy pillow: easy be thy rest, and may thy bed be.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Mortal down, thistle soft,
She laid herself under to keep him aloft,
And ever she said, come turn thee to me,
And was not this bonny lass Mary Ambre?

div1.stage: Enter Auditor, and doth whisper with Sir Rafe.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Mary indeed she hath resigned to me hard choice,
Near am I but as arrows a far of,
Seems to the shooter neighbour to the mark,
Till it prove otherwise, so I
Furthest from favour am, though seeming nigh.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Change your mark, shoot at a white, will say, come stick me in the clout sir, her white is black, it is crept into her eye, and wenches with black eyes the white is turned up are but as custards, though they seem stone cold, yet greedily attempted, burning hot, and such a wench is she sir.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: I know she loves me.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Most affectionately burns in desire for ye, but key cold through her father, she stands to freeze while others are appointed to thaw the Ice, not you.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: I must use policy.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: The only man, I will assist you sir,

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: I thank thee, and I will prevail in it.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: I think sir, if I see my house tonight, there will come warrants to make open way to their recovery, thinking they are with me, whom I protest I have, not seen, and unacquainted with her subtle stealth, am now as clear as is the babe new born, I neither knew of it, nor where they are, I do beshrew their hearts, right I have in him for it.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p:
sleep in my house then, so my word shall make your answer stronger, I have a son, I wish him so possessed, but not with violence, yet say he do climb high, and reach the top bough with a stricter course, I knowing not the manner nor the means, acquits me, and God give,
them joy, my oath is clear, and that is my warrant.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: Sir, I will trouble you tonight, by this sad time his moan doth challenge comfort, and the council whose loves he hath so often visited, heartened on by the Earl of Tumults means, they will add present purpose as he begs it.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: but if the Earl know of my sons discharge, signed by his careless answer, it would allay his hot endeavours with a cold response; but cease that, the time shall come---

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: It is mine, the cause and all, pine let me in them, if the son of hope shine as a troubled meteor in the sky; it is our fates fortune, and no matter cause no remedy.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: True vauntings of resolve, it is late, and custom challenges no right in me, to be so hurtful to myself, the evenings air is raw and cold.

sp.speaker: S. Raf.
sp.l: Filbon follow us, be you more temperate.
You see what hurry threatenings this misdeed
Wounds deep are dangerous, though they hardly bleed

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: Sir, I am lessoned,

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: As the boys at school?
Practise their knowledge by contrary rule.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: O I am slain with th wonder.
Hath this life left in it a little breath,
To blow out treason, reek ye clouds of shame,
Putrefy all imagination, hold her at stern,
There let her sink, never to win again,
Homers recovery, shall I say and think it?
Have I not been in bed tonight, and so
Talk idly wanting sleep, or rose from rest,
As many troubled do, acting like life,
Awaking dead, for in that flattering fear,
Perchance her reputation may be saved.
No I am certain in my fear, it is true,
In yond black closet lies a wicked woman,
(I will not say my mother, that names lost)
In the twined brazings of the slave her man.
In Iames his arms, and shall I suffer it?
To blab, it were to herald out my shame,
In quartered scutcheon of black obloquy,
To murder one were most impartial;
Again to turn hills on this sin,
Would write me bawd, but to be nobly satisfied
Is a content licenced from equity.
The knight shall know it, I will write to him,
Startle his bold imagination with pale fear,
Rose his revengeful spirit on them both,
And make me hopeful of his love neglected,
Forgive me world, heavens justice puts me on,
And though a son, I will punish both or none.

div1.stage: Exit. Enter Earle, and Lord, and Sir VVilliam, the Lords, and sir VVilliams two men bearing torches.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: You that bind up in secrets of the night,
Days benefits going to rest;
As peaceful birds, lodged in a sanctuary.
Smile at our Courtiers care, whose industry,
Rules in the silent and all shadowing night,
Suites that are breathless in a troubled day.
Have their abiding in our cares at night.
Hard censured, and atoned by late advice,
Salving the worlds scares, as we would your care
Knew we the burthen of it.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: With us the morn is mated with the moon
And we are retrograde to what you do.
Esteeming conscience, benefit and good.
Challenged in service of our country:
Sir though our blood affirm us labour free,
It binds thee more to busy industry,
Wonder not at our late upsitting therefore.

sp.speaker: S. Vil.
sp.l: Your humours toil in our extremities,
But we unthankful merit contrary,
Think it a want and weakness in our kind,
I post and labour in a toil myself,
Seeking my own: midnight to me is noon,
And all the hours of dull past night,
Sun-shine eclipses, that do much molest me,
Pardon me that am so tedious.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: Seeking your own.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: My eldest daughter is conveyed from me,
Hurried away, as thieves by violence
Convey their booties from the true mans store.
Auditor, Toures son hath done this deed,
A rescue noble Lords.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: Rescue and right, challenge the benefit.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: A warrant for a general search,
Restraints for Cinck-ports, and all passages,
That thievish water doth despoil us of.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: It shall be signed in the morning,
Draw the contents as you affect the means,
And let attendance urge the early act.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Good night.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: God morrow is it not?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Betwixt them both.
The moral of my misery seeking too late,
That to recover which I lost too soon.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And yet in each you stand indifferent.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: I must, till perfected by you,
Either late loss, or timely victory,
Recovering what I fear is past advantage.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Hope the best sir, things at worst,
Season in their decay, as children mend,
Bent in their eye to ruin, yet they pause
Resting in grace, does re-obtain at will,
Opinion in rash judgment, dooming ill.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Good rest, for we go to it.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.l: The peace of happiness be with ye,
I will retire me to my Inn, and wish,
Hours as short as momentary breath,
For till the morning, minutes hours be,
And hours years, such is revenged to me,
Might I enjoy it?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: My man, a midnight messenger, what is thy haste in lethe steeped, speak is that all one? one all, that we call daughter, gone too, is she?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Wherefore starest thou so wildly, say, wert thou asleep and wakened? comest to us here without thy better part? and sent abroad, leaving thy wits at home.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your son sir, in all haste sends you his tales, wishes your wit and judgment suddenly, read and regard sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Give the torch, if you will see my mother and your wife, fellowed in bed make haste, Iames your man writes on your pillow etc. my eyes are witnesses to their adultery.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.p: What is the news?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Plague on these jauntings, once we shall be old, and then this trotting life will linger in our bones, all hours are our nights, we dally with our own destruction.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: It cannot be, or if, or if, what if? if it be so I am undone, poisoned am I with fair promises, no marvel though you do forswear my bed, if yet again, if what make I here when treason is at home, away.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: The bird that greets the dawning of the day,
Signs with his wings, the midnight's parture,
And the sleety dew moistening the cheeks
Of morrows welcome: gives earnest of the morn:
Yet all secure, adulterate lust does sleep,
And I the hatched yong of this trodden hen,
Stands Sentinel to her idolatry.
Blow you swelled winds and crack the battlements,
Rouse their incestuous luxury with fear
Of what is to come, yet that were my mishap,
No silent air fan on them bawdy breath.
That as they reek in their licentious love,
Devil may seal sure, and Morpheus so pleased,
May to their pastime add affliction
Delivered by the hand of him that is wronged,
And stands indebted to his destiny:
Yet are they as the hour, whose sandy minutes
Runs out at pleasure till the period comes,
Fast sleeping, and enjoy their quiet,
Rouse the black mischief from thy ebony cell,
Land in the bosoms of this twin in lust,
Him whose heapt-wrong calls vengeance to be just.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Lock fast that door and leave me. Give me your light, Son Humil?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Father.

div1.stage: Enter sir William and his men.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Thou seest I am obedient at thy call.
sp.l: I come as messengers that bring their bale,
Signed in their looks, be well advised,
Thou makest a challenge goes beyond all grace,
Should it be false.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: It is my love to you that makes me step
Heart-deep in disobedience to my mother.
Wretch that I am to think her so,
It makes me desperate of priority,
Forethinking my beginning to be base,
Conceived in such mistrust and frailty,
My front hath that impression still,
Adding a blush to my distemperature,
And I am crestfallen in sanguinity,
Pray ye believe me, would it were not so.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Enough watch and be secret, I will enter,
Sit as the night raven or the screeching owl,
Over my portal, menacing ill chance
To all within: for death is to my blood
A blessing, while this fever kills,
Almost my intellect or better part,
Yet she is thy mother, and no son but hates
His own disgrace so highly merited,
And I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Sir, truth is truth, my conscience and religion
Binds up in me, and since I do proclaim
Detraction from my blood, by her misdeed,
Give me leave to report a fly a fly,
If it offend the virtue of mine eye.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: It is true.
And yet methinks it should not be,
How hardly will this scandal take impression,
Where resolved christianity does dwell?
But I will try the gold, perhaps it is base,
Who knows the hearts affection by the face.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Scarlet is scarlet, and her sin blood red,
Will not be washed hence with a sea of water,
Is this my hand, or is the fire fire?
whose scorching heat dissolves releting metal,
When as it tries the substance; yes, and I
Make known my mother is an alien,
From my blood, so to fall off, and perish
Even in her pride of bliss, damned be the slave
That so attempts her spotless chastity
To ruin, I know that yet smooth look,
Plotted, contrived, and won her with devise,
She never knew a double character till now,
But single singler she ever ruled,
Even modesty herself, Vesta resigned to her,
And virtue hand in hand at barley-break,
Ran the swift course, none but a hound of hell,
Hunted this fawn of fortune to his kennel,
But my mother, forgetting her degree,
Does captivate love, life and liberty,
By one deeds practise, wicked, nay far worse,
Fatal disgrace, honours created course.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Fool, fool, fool.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Light bubble swell and break, wouldst thou believe all this, and give a gloss to slanders cruelty: ripening reproach itself with thy fond ear, o Humil, Humil.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Thou art a villain, and hast cast up hills against heaven itself: when sons unto their mothers are so false, O where is grace? hood winked from honour, shamed to show her face.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Is it not so?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Trust thy own eyes, go, thou shalt see a sight
Will melt thy stubborn spleen in pity,
Sweetly she sleeps, whose innocent respect
Smiles in her dreams, the childlike govern,
Laughing loud in their simplicity,
While waking, mischief seeks that to undo,
Which true required, stands sentinel unto,
Go and return with shame.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: With shame, devil of mischance what is this?
Did I not see their cutted guilt look big?
Was I in trance of my belief, ha, was I?
Can be no juggling in it: can there?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: No thou art constant as the northern star,
And I as giddy as the untamed Leopard,
That sees no means but dire destruction,
Flinging his foam to poison in his way
Mans mischief, plotted to his overthrow:
He told me true, o that I live to think so,
Or they so wretched to deserve the thought,
Soundly they slept, whose slobbers kissed me waking,
Yet to recover half slain reputation,
Done have I, what to purpose practiseth
If it prevail, our honour so reserved
Will kick at all malignant cruelty
That taints our name with ever living scorn,
Fortune be for me, I will that recover,
Which devil himself cries guilty too, my fame
The flight it wings, imps feathers of renown,
That left all is lost, my birth-right tumbles down,

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Sir I am sorry.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: How can they excuse such wanton looseness? know they I stand here to thunder vengeance on their luxury.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: My mother is fast asleep, and I awake, am in a transiue maze, unwitting how to make my peace with God herself and you.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: why are they not together?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Not in bed.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.l: Thou shouldest with Argos hundred eyes,
Search in the chinks and corners round about,
It cannot be but she is extant there, ha, is she not?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I am confounded in the search, please your justice be my torture, I have murdered innocence, sorrow is not the way, death is the least, I challenge cruelty and urge the exactest point of peril, slave that I am to live.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: A son, a son, to do so to a mother.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Fare ye well, rather than be a witness of my wrong,
I will not see myself in it, go thou worse then,
I will sacrifice to the devil, that tempted thee, all thy
Distempered thoughts, cry mercy to her sects.
To spotless innocence be free, say all thy treasons,
Build on slippery ice, and thou art frozen cruelty,
Sir, for your wrongs, if you remit black torture, it is
My hell, and I appeal to stern rigour, O you sons,
Whose true obedience shines in majesty.
While mine more ugly than is vulcans tithye.
Smells ranker than despised Hemlock
Curse and ban him, I am your subject to it
And every mother, whose snow innocence,
Feels soft and tender, as the down on palm,
Rate my rebellion with a blissless name,
And for my sake give misadventure aim.
Guide them to me, say I am such son,
Through whom a mother is so soon undone,

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: Let me not see the while thou livest away,
Let thy repentance show itself in this,
Not to be seen where thou hast done amiss.
Caitiff depart.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I will, this tongue that slandered,

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.p: Be her slander still.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: It is too much already, was I bewitched,
That thus at hud-man blind I dallied
With her I honoured? O you times how have you
Nursed me, but no more, Humil hath branded on his
Mothers name, an Aethyops blackness, and
A spotted stain, forgive me that and all.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: What need I to afflict revenge on him
That on himself exasperates, farewell thou pride
Of sons, who to a father in supposition only and
by law, art all so loving, that thy mother dalling
With watones as girls with gauds, thou not respects
The womb that brought thee forth, but ill attempting
So, and so thou rumourest, as the fault ripe in act,
Is blown to air, and though her son thou
Utterest what they were, thou shalt not loose by it
Now it fits, I challenge from the offence some right,
And add confine to this adultery
Wife, wife, rise and come forth.

div1.stage: Enter Lady, in her night gowne, and night attire.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Call ye sir?

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: Yes, take my closet key, let forth your lover,
Give me some ease by way of reason yet, and it will
Allay our discontent, O God so new to marriage, and
So stale, couldst thou so soon revolt, so soon, ha?

div1.stage: Enter Iames vnready, in his night-cap, garterles with the Lady.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I must acknowledge all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O No, some better looze,
This will but add to mischief torture
Use patience now be reconciled to fear,
Be dove-like humble, and leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Iame.
sp.l: How can I, when the brand is on my brow,
But by exclaim, give ease to torture,
My brain is scared, and I am liveless in it?

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.p: Kneel not.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: A sentence, let us die.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: No marvel though you vow this abstinence
When deputed by him, you shun my bed,
You do deserve your jointer well,
To admit a fellow in a true mans place,
I thank ye for it, yes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: No, no words I know you can allege,
The devil has scripture for his damned ill,
And this does neighbour it, go and attire ye.
Be smilefull, and express no grief in sithes,
Rather be tickling sportful, topped in pleasure.
Than daunted any way, that me concerns.
To use the mad-mans guise, but I am past it,
Since what is done no reference hath to wish,
I am for credit sake, supportable, all is well,
Content am I to be sensible, and feel my
Fortunes as I may, ranking myself with such,
As sometime lived in my repute most base,
Faith all is well believe it, I am satisfied:
I know you do repent, and that is my remedy,
Other amends, I look not for, In and attire ye,
But stay you with me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am obedient.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: Go thou shame, never till now possessed,
And in a breath confounded, sir, you see your wrongs
Shine through the horn, as candles in the eve,
To light out others, think you this misdeed,
Merits salvation?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I must acknowledge contrary.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: Wilt thou for all this spite, yet use me kindly in the next?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Command me sir.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Not for the second, this mistake me not,
Rather to bind thee from it, if hereafter,
Fashion of frailty summon us to fear
I must be plain, and therefore thus:
Look when so ever I hold up this finger,
Signing my lips with it, and cry begone,
Even then be speedy to depart the land.
If not all power of mischief that I can, I will
and so resolve.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Sir, I am ready to the minute.

sp.speaker: S. VVi.
sp.l: It may be, other reasons will restrain me
As causeless motives, nor seeing guiltiness.
In needy sequences perhaps our heart will in itself take truce with this mischance,
or if it do not, yet attend our spleen, it will be better for ye.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: In humble duty.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: Go, give copies of good countenance to our friends, think all is well, for so it is, I that am all in grief, am all in suffering, I forgive the reason, Fate ye well.
sp.l: What I will do, is barred up in this closet,
The key that opens it, is my revenge
Turned by a hand whose palm does itch with fire
Till all consume, a cuckold, cuckold William fir is
Its even so, would I were yet the last or least,
But not by thousands go too then, am I all alone, in this
Who is it that tongue calls man
That is assured of his wives conditions
None, or if any, there the Phoenix hues
Vnfellowed, be his fate renowned while mine
Is mockery, and a Testiue stock, to all that knows me.
O you stars blaze fire, till this abuse be quenched
By my desire.

div1.stage: Enter Tutch like a welch knight, and Filbon as a seruant waiting.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Hark ye Morris.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Aye Sir.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Where is Tailer? dudge me, will knog his pad,
What is chirken with cold button done, say you.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: Excellent, this is welch indeed, O my honest Tutch.
Sauce box, rowly powly, am I not your master?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: You are sir, pray ye pardon me.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: You must have your left eye Diameter wise,
Fixed on my right heel, and all the offices,
A servant owes in duty to his Master, perform
As naturally as if the forty shilling time
Were come, left I leave talking welch, and crack your pate in English.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: I shall obey sir.

div1.stage: Enter M. Auditor in a Marchants habite, with Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: Fairest of beauties, love her seemly self,
For thy two eyes are Cupids, which do shoot
From thy enamoured bow, shafts all of gold,
Headed with metal of immortal proof.
In thy fair bosom lives two hearts relenting,
Thine penetrable, through atoning pity,
Mine longing by desire to scale the fort
Of loves fair presence, make me happy,
Sign to my suit, but ye, for it is thy censure
Makes me thus bold, pronounce fair judgment,
Either of life or death, I that plead love,
Doubly devoted, challenge from thy deity
A maiden answer, let it come bright fire,
To try the substance of my loves resolve.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Sir, in sooth and verity believe me,
That I am fair it is credible, but to shoot
Arrows, whose heads have such immortal proof,
It is most erroneous and false, 'sfoot your a puritan,
A citizen I am sure, her canvas currant bags,
Stuffed with sweet cinnamon and cloves,
Good sir you are deceived in me; I am country plain
Without this nicety, and do you love me, yes?
Then crave an answer without ceremony,
Fetched from proud Ouid in his Arte amandi,
I do not like it I.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Please you Lady.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sir and you, tell me of Cupids eyes, shot from enamoured bows with hearts relenting, doubly devoted, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Please you firkin.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: No sir no, give me plain courtesy,
Drawing on loves white hand a glove of warmth,
Not cheverel, stretching to such profanation,
You overthrow loves deity in this,
And putrefy his altars with bad breath.
I am a dairy housewife, no such wanton,
So easily flattered with far fetched replies.
Yet I esteem this worthless person free,
And though not fair, yet something fortunate.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Hark ye now Lady.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sir cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Was a knight, mark you, of English in Wales, welsh blood, and it is no mock in en to marry in welsh blood, is it?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sir all the smiles a modest maid, can in this kind make proffer of, are yours, in your fair welcome, blame me not, though his unkindness made me negligent in your kind entertain.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: Neglect me so.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Wives unto Citizens are trades-mens daughters,
I am a blood of gentle composition,
My mind does equal it, I must be coached,
Bankrupt every where, courted abroad,
At home flattered, for my private use,
I must have fancies, playfellows, as apes,
Monkeys, baboons, muffs, fans, receipts,
Costly habiliments of several suites,
Will ye give this? it will break you sir,
And crack your credits fair condition, no,
Citizens would, but cannot answer so.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Hark you, marry with her, and God dudge me, all is yours, was a knight have land, and a great deal of riches, will maintain you well, say you.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: This gentleman or this, before a Citizen, you sir pardon me I will have none.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: Then whom you will, call you this modesty to be so waspish? given to slight men off with incivility, give me leave to remember.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: What you please, all the world except one or two, my eye motes that trouble but my sight. Filbon for me, man else but mere illusion and idolatry, vain worship, images of molten metal, which to dross dissolved, appear as nothing to my judgment, but his worth beyond compare, gentle and suffering as the silent air, that though it brooke the buffets of base breath, yet in itself it is heavenly, free from earth.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Hark you, was knight in house called Sir William Perger.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Verger sir?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Morris was say true, give a ducat, look you tuck it, is mark, mark you that, and mark is 13 shillings four pence, good current money, and how do you? well, when was sir Robert Morgan, mik you lady, grace a God.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: You sir.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Was I lie pray you?

div1.stage: Enter Sir William, sir Rafe, Henry, a Priest of Putney.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Think you Master Auditor, knew nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rafe.
sp.p:
Upon my soul I think it. I did wind him subtly as hounds the game,
New got on foot, for instance he lamented oft his sons proceedings, neglecting his own house, lest you in quest of her should search it, believe me sir I tell you what I know.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: It is likely, sons in these doting days
Will from their fathers alienate, differ still
From loves obedience, and in hearts affection,
Join hand to hand, though beggary neighbour it,
And let them go.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Sir I am free then from your fear.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Aye good sir Henry I was wrong informed,
I am your patron in all love.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Long may ye live, so sir I find you gentle,
And a good benefactor to poor scholars,
We have few such, many we rather have,
That sell the Church rights, then maintain them,
And in my next stanza, I shall tickle them.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Speak conscience and no more.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Nay as for that sir pardon me,
I seldom exercise without that thought,
What my text leads me to, I will pronounce,
Maugre the devil of judgment.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Soft.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Bless you gallant knight, a merchant sir, Of London am I, my estate secure, and so it please you covet this fair maid in marriage, nothing else.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Know you him Sir Rafe?

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: Not well sir, but by guess, he is indifferent rich, has broke three times, made his head hole by means, and that say I, as this world shapes, is secure policy, what think you sir?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: I do not think it so, though common practise finds it furthering shifts, do the devil resemble, and bankrupt baseness makes good credit tremble, like it not.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.p:
Please you Aunt, hark you now, knight was love this firkin, and God will, must make her wife, shall be her lacy,
go in Wales, great worship God willing.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: O know this knight, he was created the other day.

sp.speaker: S Raf.
sp.p: Sir Rober Morgan, O sir, such a one, whose reputation reacheth to the best, merits a good conjunction, were it my daughter, she should have him, O beware when majesty shines in a mans estate.
sp.l: They long stand firm, spread wide regenerate
And though base born, yet honour makes them swell,
Like clustered grapes, till mature sweetness brings,
Luscious conclusion.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: I have some mind to him, sir you receive
Kind welcome, let it store your thoughts with
Those sweet motions lovers wish to enjoy, she may,
perchance, all things concluded on, before ye.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.l: Was a clad man, Morris fetch trunk of apparel
was lie here a four week, will not out now.
Was welcome, plague on you, was love ye.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.p: Sir, as for you, being city proud, my daughters look sits on a Courtiers brow, what sayst my girl?

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: O sir, a Courtier on my life, I love to sit up late,
Lie long in the morning, rot with sweet meats, and
To play at shuttle-cock, methinks the games now
In my arms, in any hand a Courtiers wife and
Why not his blackiet shows best about
Beauties neck, and I am proud of such
A surer, if I understand not his welsh, like
A good piece of ordinance, I shall lie fast upon the
Bulwark, and discharge my obedient English
Must be a Lady sir.

sp.speaker: S VVil.
sp.p: Yet welcome sir, let it not grieve you.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Seignior no, you are welcome to the wife I woo,

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And mistress, might I be the man to strike the stroke.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: You, or else none, sir Henry.

sp.speaker: S VVill.
sp.p: Troth she says true, but listen me for that, come Gallants enter with me, we will feast, there is little labour lost, where trial bids presumption scyrre the coast.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Right to a hair, it is mine, and I must do it
I see my fees, my rich advantage, sirrah boy,
Shall we have work, in faith and shall we?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Conclude, I will busy him, Sir Rafe.

sp.speaker: S. Raf.
sp.l: Son, you see to what a happy issue this disguise
Speaks fair, you know the plots, boldly proceed,
It is ours in action, but your own the deed, I must
Shun all suspicion by my presence, look to it boy.
If thou failest now, for ever loose thy joy.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, master, I a Welshman, a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: A trick now on my maiden-head, I did mistrust it, Come leave the rest to me, this Priest shall marry us incontinent.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: Aye, if I were the Welshman. Because your father gave him light thereto. Therefore come sirrah, we will shift clothes, meet us at Putney as my father shall mistrust ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Rafe.
sp.p: I will, excusing your departure till anon,

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: do gentle love. Heaven on our venture smiles, this to approve.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: O it cannot choose.
Fathers are fortunate in this good news.
Go ye drones, ye do not love the hive,
There is honey in it, it is a sweet thing to win.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I must break the ice for ye, if I slip up to the chin, now you will pull me out, save me from drowning mistress.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Fear it not.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I would be loath betwixt Welch and English, to be hanged, mistress, I cannot live on the bargain, come sir, I will shift with them, and now I must shift with you.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: Aye clothes, good Tutch.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: And use me no worse being your man, than I used you, being mine.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: O better, better.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.p: O love, thou art a beggar, yet I am thy debtor.
