div1.stage: Enter two sailers with a truncke, wherein is Mistresse Mary in her winding sheete, others with pick-axe and spades, as on the sands.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Set down the heaviest load
That ever true affection underwent,
To you it is like the Anchor of your ship,
Heavy at first, but easily weighed seems light,
To me, that not supports her bodies weight,
It is heart deep in the burthen, and too ponderous
Sad, heavy is that load, whose leaden poise,
Is as a sullen sorrow, too, too pressing.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: Sir, I would wish you to be brief.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Dig ho this golden beach, whose glittering sands
Shows with the sun as Diamonds set in gold,
Fitly entombs a jewel of much worth,
Whose living beauty stained all lapidary.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: She was most gentle which was worth all riches.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: And this nights tempest did a cruel deed,
To take from me a value of such price.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: Sir, though our seas kill women with their frowns us their bugbear threats are womanish, and so we leave them

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Leaving yourself and all, sometime,

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Even so, no safer in our beds,
Or on the land, but under deaths black stroke,
And he that is the surest, sits in state,
Dyingly tended by the hand of Fate.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: And yet methinks death should not
Take her from me, being scarce mine own.
But newly wed, never bedded yet.
So that the Ceremony burning bright,
Himen yet hath his tapers flaming red.
And the bold boastings of that good mans breath.
That all religiously made one of two.
Hardly digested in the freezing cold,
Little I thought the priests word being, ever,
Should find his period in so short a time.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Sir, but the gift was given ye on condition,
Till death depart, better or worse,
Methinks this Catechising little needs,
To human guiding, and to you the less
Knowing what openly you do confess.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Bear with me master, he that pines in grief,
Lives as you sailors do, thinking at sea,
Every storm ends, when flattery flouts ye,
So to our love-sick sorrow comes a calm,
By ease of fancies, when it is furthest,
And many times the weapon that doth wound,
Is salve, and Surgeon both, to make all sound.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: Are ye ready sir?

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: All fitted, let me take my last farewell,
I am all jelly in my tears and sighs,
Wasted by waiting her untimely loss,
So long I did consume in drops of woe,
That contrary I laugh to think it so.
He that weeps much, having no tears to spend,
Smiles out the rest, but inwardly does rend,
O God that I venturing so hard a chance,
Should loose my dice, before my hand be out,
It is even so, in all things man intends
The loss is ours, the winnings not our friends.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: For charity be brief, should the wind
Turn his beak into the southern side
Our ship would leave us, dally not with grief,
Once and no more, let sorrow rule as chief.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Then thus, and this the last,
Moll, I take leave yet on thy hearsed self,
Dead self, and self slain Moll desist
I am thy morning music, call thee up,
To wedded rights, I lead thee to the Church,
And there receive thee, dine with thee at noon,
Dance all the after day, bring thee at night
Into the wedding chamber, this is it.
And here I leave thee to thy virgin slumber,
Never attempted, as thy birth bestowed,
Madam beginning, take it in thy end,
So live thus die, only my married friend,
And nothing else, gone art thou to a power,
Which will with welcomes take thee, left I am
To the worlds cross, thy father who enraged,
Will bitterly revenge thy death on me,
But I will prove his martyr, se-thee Moll,
Fool that I am to say so, here is all,
Gowns, tire, all habiliments of thine,
No rag shall rest remembrant in my view.
To stir the embers of thy dying fire,
I kiss thy key cold corse, and with this key,
Lock thee for ever up, farewell, farewell,
My mouth the Church, my voice thy
Parting knell. All ears that live and hear
This bell to toll, Christian-like bid peace unto
her soul.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Amen, be speedy mates, see ye not, look
The blueness of yon cloud does threaten wind,
If it rise fair, we shall be lodged in France,
But not where please the fates. Dispatch.

sp.p: A board, a board, heie.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Hollo, linger no time aboard, you hear
With me ho, will the rest stay? how a year?
O God that man should leave behind,
And live, the love of soul and mind.

div1.stage: Exeunt, and leaue the pikax and spades behinde. Enter Gouernour and a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gouernor.
sp.l: Sir welcome to Scillie,
Where I command my brothers friends have welcome,
But now my flattery gets you on this beach,
Where you prospective see many countries,
Learn this of me, where dagger shoots her string,
We in our neighbour nearness ought to fear:
But armed by our foresight, make bold resist
Against the brags of foreign enemies.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: I have not seen a better glass to look in,
What country call you yon, whose cliffs are as the clouds
smoke, and all shadowing mists?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Sir that is France, a fair beseeming friend,
On yonder continent stands Ireland,
On this side Britain, and on that side Garsie,
Islands besides of much hostility,
Which are as sun-shine, sometimes splendious,
Anon disposed to altering frailty.
We that all neighbour must so strength our being,
As fearless we may frolic yet not seeing.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: I understand ye sir.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Now let my longing have content in you,
With the report of them you lately saw,
My brother Vergirand his children,
Is he a widower still at More-clacke?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Married sir unto a London cast a way,
One whose decayed husband left to live,
(Though poorly) yet your brothers Lady.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: It is his choice, and I subscribed to it, But for his daughters sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Alas, in them is he unhappy,
One is hailed from him by stolen practises,
The other lives as though she were not his,
A goodly gentle woman, but her own in heart,
She will be gone too, for her government
Stands upon will, as men stand on the beach,
Seeing the sea wherein they must be drowned,
Yet fearless venture on the ruthless maine,
She will regardless of her father, marry,
And does as most, long for the misery,
Signed to them in their cradles.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Sorry am I.
Ha, what scrambled ends heap up confusedly?
New digged and ripped up is this plot of ground,
Some Shipwreck on my life, hid to deceive
The Queen and me of our advantages.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: Likely sir,
And see our sudden coming scared from hence,
In the new ending, such as piled this heap,
Behind them have they left their implements
Which did the theft, what think ye sir if we
Re-dig the ground, should we depart and leave it?
At midnight wold they fetch their borrowings.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: I like your purpose, I will make one.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: What do you think it is sir?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: No body buried, it is sure some goods,
wracked on the sea, money or rich commodity,

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Tobacco then.

sp.speaker: Gouernor.
sp.p: It is likely, for with us men smoke their lands thorough their nostrils, shall I tell ye sir, it is a commodity may well be spared.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: Good luck a gods name, sir it is a trunk.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Lift sir.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: It is quick, it heaved as I heaved it.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: in faith I think so too, in heart of hope I will be all so bold, as to break way.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: Ha.

div1.stage: They breake the Truncke open, and she sits vp.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: If you be men and born of that weak sex,
Which I myself profess, being woman,
Pity the living sorrow of a maide,
Buried for dead, but back again recalled,
By the divinity of heavenly power,
Amaze not, I am creature, flesh and blood,
Not as I seem, a pale and earthly Ghost,
The story when you hear it shall make plain,
The woeful chance of life so lately slain.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: I had acquaintance with this voice, my cousin.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: It is she, sir, it is Mistress Mary Virger, I know her.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.l: My name recalls my memory,
And I am such a creature, O,
My uncle, where am I? return again,
Death thou art wanton in a lovers pain.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Cousin I will not question the particulars,
The time calls on a present comfort,
And your life half spent,
Makes true necessity delay no longer,
Therefore come, as leisure we shall hear,
The dying story of your misery.
How ever, glad I am that such a chance,
Landed in Scilly not in neighbouring France.

div1.stage: Enter in Filbon in welch attire, and Tutch in seruingmans, like one another, with them S. Rafe, M. Auditor and Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: If ever you used speed, be swift as lightning,
Shoot as the stars in their celestial spheres,
Go and return as Paris did from Greece,
With that im matchless Hellen, tell the Priest
It must be done, he will believe your haste,
Because it was quickened with the former grant,
And promised by the knight himself,

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: Let me alone to make the way, follow you son.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: And if I do not let me loose my prize.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: Wheres the knight?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Busy with one, who comes as conjured up from Cupids quiver, stricken deep in love, he is a Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I know him his mother was a.

sp.speaker: Audi.
sp.p: Peace. Him will I busily attend, go you dispatch while I detain the father, if this prove, it is comic pleasure in the school of love.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: We must be quick and sudden, come.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Slip like your Eel.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: If any man know any lawful cause why these two may not marry, now speak, or else for ever mum, I am gone in faith.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Master, remember, you have my tongue.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: yes, and thou mine, let me alone to counterfeit,

div1.stage: exeut Enter sir William with Humil, like a Pothecary.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: Think on your oath.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Sir, if I do not, let me dye.
When I have poisoned her with this confection:
Be you cloudy killed with sorrow, it is a skin,
Will draw to purpose on the straightest glove,
But then your promised reward.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.l: My daughter and my goods,
I have no other son but you, all is thine,
Question not the reason, why this is,
For I have many, and amongst them one
Sites all the rest, that known to thee,
Will rather hasten death, than pity it.
Go, I will bid my guests, for to this feast:
Shall she have noble poison, it will cause fear,
Use less suspicion, and my mortal hate,
Shall itself kenuell in the pride of state.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: give order for the banquet,

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: within there.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, what is your will

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: To murder thee,

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: She dies sir, if I live, I am a Apothecary.
And can knead the paste to purpose, she is gon
Had she a thousand lives laid up in one.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.l: Wife, I must have thee paint,
And set a gloss upon this lovely front,
To move, and to attract all eyes look as the summer,
Which glads all hearts with his blood-creasing spring:
Use thy best graces, though most proudly
I will have it so, fit thee to all state,
Decked in thy choicest ornament, shine glowworm,
In the noon of night, for at this supper.
I will have more than all our friends,
Music several, Masques and Revellings.
In which thou shalt be mounted as the bride,
And I the jolly Bridegroom, will tend on thee,
As duty and the time commands me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where of comes this cost?

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.l: Examine not, but lay your best end now to it
Council with this Apothecary which I sent for
To the business, pray ye use your art:
For I am bent to this consumption,
Wheres our servant Iames?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Within sir, shall I call him?

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.l: No, I will wait on him, for it is my duty.
Such as would spend in feasts, are but the slaves,
To attend the pleasures of consuming knaves.
And I am one of those, he is the flower
That I must crop too in this fatal hour.
Pray ye appoint sir, she will fit you well,
My purse shall purvey what you shall determine,
What we will be wasteful sometime, etc our own,
We uncontrolled may dispose of: it is our love,
Rather our destiny, hate joined to this brow,
A horn that draws on death, no matter how.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, in my closet serve yourself with sugars, there are spices of the purest, use them in this cost, what else you want, please you command, they shall attend you.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: I want virtue in a mother, are you one?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am a mother to an absent son,
But not to virtue wanting, wrong me not.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Wrong not yourself.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I never will.

div1.stage: he discouers himselfe to his mother.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: You have.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Humil, O my shame and not my son. By thee a mother is made miserable.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: By me black sin? no by thy own neglect, made perfect by my true intelligence, and how ever cunning masked and donned the vizard that so muffled me, I knew not who was in the bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Your eyes were witnesses.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: And holy ones.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Found you the man you looked for?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: No, it was a subtle strain, so hoodwinked truth, I am a traitor if I did not see Iames your man fast in your arms.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thou art a traitor then, if any Iames were there, he was no man of mine, he was thy father.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Marvel not, at leisure I will tell thee all,
His late return, the trick to place him here,
My stay, and his continuing in this house, which
Known, thou wilt no sin account, to keep our own.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: O you prophetic Fairies, how dally you,
In concaves of our hearts, shamed at my error
I thought for ever to be from your sight,
But thinking, truth was blinded, I forethought
Some following business, thus I altered
Coming as one disguised to save her life,
Damned for that fact.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My life?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: You must be poisoned at this feast,
It is I must do the deed, O mother,
How are you blessed in my return from travel,
I that to light bring your offence, so thought,
Must be the pardon at your judgment brought.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah me.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: No more, much secrecy calls on us,
Acquaint me with my father, plead my guilt.
We shall with cunning so unfold this business,
That our hopes shall strengthen as they perish,
No idle practise, but a serious toil,
Must bring home conquest from this long wished spoil.

div1.stage: Enter Henry, Filbon, Tabitha, Sir Rafe, Tutch.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: If I lock up this treason, let me perish,
sp.l: No sir, my breast is yet an incorrupt and holy house,
That harbours in it, nought but honesty, and to do
This wrong to my patron, per deum atque hominem fidem.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: No matter if you tell it now, it is done, finismen
Say, concludes the ancient work, and this
Though newly done, cries so be it.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: If keep secrets, can be but offence, and so it is now,
May be, I loose my place, but there is a friend which
Turning calls detraction, at his heels lives hope,
Whose cunning quickness every fault to favour.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Why true, and we shall as we may excuse it,
It was a deed done in welch, you understood it not.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: Let me alone to buckler thee sir Henry.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Can ye ward yourself?

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: This was a pass, it was Fencers play, and for the after venny, let me use my skill.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: How ever girl, thou art my daughter now,
What thou shalt loose in father, from thy own,
Thou uncontrolled shalt find as much in his,
And I am he.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: And I acknowledge both this in my Lord, my head, my husband, at whose bed Lam obedient, at whose board I am obedient: all in all, I am the wife of Filbon, whose rough Welch, hath got a construing English, parse it boy, Nouns, Pronouns, Verbs, Adverbs, and God give thee joy.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: With vocative O, your father hears it.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: And ablative caret, takes his daughter.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then in pluraliter, ah has a son.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: So singular and plural all is done.

div1.stage: Enter Auditor, like a Merchant still.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: If ever you were swift be nimble now, what have ye married, tide this knot?

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: Aye, and the earnest blow given, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Sir, I have set my hand to it, sealed the deed,
Pray God it cancel not in me.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Then part, and every one be silent.
There is a feast appointed at the knights.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Our marriage dinner, is it?

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: A gallant one, much cost is threatened. And the good old knight unbuckles from his back, the liberal load of honour, does proclaim triumphs, and welcome unto all, calls for his wife, charges her care, commands his servant Iames to invite his guests, which in a role stands quoted, there is a new come apothecary, and he bribes, even grace herself in this assembly, and does promise his furtherance in the business, on the sudden you are missed, daggers and devils the knight cries wheres my daughter? one up ascends to search the chambers, another runs to seek for this lost daughter. I knowing more than much in this her absence, singled myself to warn you of his search, hither will he come, for he fears yong Filbon, missing the suitors, calling for the merchant, I answered not (being absent) in this heat: the welch man, where is he? none can be found, cries out he knows not what, and all his word is now, a plot, a plot, a plot.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: What will ye do?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Kiss and part, till fit occasion of our next salute, Filbon farewell, my husband think on me, I am thy treasure but thou bearest the key.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: I will home.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: And I will see the rest, what will you sir do?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Nay I have done enough, I am undone in myself, Hei mihi quod nullos, I must do this deed, it was I pauca the rest, I will home sir, I.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: What rests for welch sir Robert Morgan, by God was crag the pen, and the hangman calls to me, da hum a, da hum a?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: I will be at this feast in some disguise.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I will fit ye sir, it is here, I am turch right, hic & vbique, every where.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Now smiles the instant, and wrathes wrinkles seem,
As smoothed curls upon a wanton stream,
My hopes grow big, and their delivery,
Is by our midwife time brought to true birth,
I will not be a pointing stock to the world,
No, if this gossip rumour publish it,
It shall be christened with revenge and death,
Why when, are we grown sluggards now?
Tardy in bounty, shall we niggard it?

div1.stage: Enter Humil in white sleeues and apron, and others posting ouer the stage with boxes.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Be quick, carry those sweet meats in,
Bid them that in this business have to do,
That they attend this rich confectionery,
With no common care, the cost commands more love
And duty, sir we are fitting to occasion,
Would all your guests were come.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: It is the feasts duty to attend,
Thou art a willing mischief, hast thou fitted
our purpose to the proof?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Have I, think you I am flack?
Pushed on with hope of beauty and reward,
She dies had she a life more dear
Than the last spring, sole comfort of the year.
But I will cover and prepare.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Do, do, my daughters thine, my goods, my all,
Blessed beginning to my sorrows fall.
Wheres my Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Here.

div1.stage: Enter Lady gallant and braue, while Humil and others prepare.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: That one so heavenly fair should earthly be,
Slave to misfortune, base in luxury.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir for to please your eye, I am thus quaint,
Good faith I am ashamed in myself.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: How and a woman.
Come blaze thy affections to immodesty,
And though thy virtues contradict the deed,
Be Venus wanton, smile, with Helens eye,
For I will have it so.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I was not so brought up: I shall endeavour, though my cheeks put on sensible die of other bashfulness.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Sir your honourable guests are come.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nay then you wrong me most of all,
Show not these signs of fear, all is past,
And I am dead in old remembrance,
Troth I am, forget it, as I do, say on.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Coaches so fill the pavements of your door,
That scarce can passage give the footmen way,
It is not amiss you go to meet them sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Why well said, spoke with courage, and I will,
Jovial like a bridegroom, Lady you see,
They wait on us, and all attend on thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Worthless I am, but since it is your will,
I borrow light from sun-shine of your beams,
Who glistens so, gives splendour nothing proud,
Darkened by fear, half hidden in a cloud.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nay hand in hand, in faith Iames pardon me,
That dally with the darling of your heart.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Even so, but little thinking such a thing,
Small gain springs from that toil, where industry
Sweats in the brows of others victory.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Father be mindful, this presuming knight,
Plays with the flame, burns in the candle-light,
When we shall furnish to disfurnish him,
Of what he yet enjoys.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Humil, it is cunningly contrived, and I attend it.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: For charity be swift.
Place your plate, and pile your vitriol bowls
Nest upon nest, These for wines and bear,
The other tend the call of altering diet,
Sirrah, quoth he, we shall sit I trow,
The pleasant purpose of loves appetite,
And hand in faith, and welcome to the feast,
Whose food is pleasure, dainties but a jest.
And I provide it for ye.

div1.stage: Enter Earle, Lords, Ladies, so many as may be, S.Wil.and his Ladie in complement.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Right noble and my hearts endored friends,
To preach your welcome, were to drown the sea
With floods of water. Be it known unto ye,
That your coming solemnly invited,
Hath that attendance appertaining as the Gods
In their selected Bacchiuels command,
Mary, the Nectar wants, and the Ambrosia,
Smiles in the presence of such earthly wines,
As the worlds compound furnishes with all,
Though it come short of luscious surfeiting:
Yet willing furtherance makes the value meet,
In her best suite of entertain, sit then,
And let our music relish to the ear:
Such care and cost as love and welcome gives,
Not to profane the best except the least,
As prolong to begin this worthless feast.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: Sir we are easily won to fawn on friendship,
Spaniel-like, yet with the smiles of men,
Which redelivers love for love,
What we receive are treasures safely stored,
And shall with interest be repaid again,
Your free, yet frugal, without lavishing,
Nor come we to make boot of courtesy,
But value kindness in her best of love,
So we dwell in your bounty.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Rent-free welcome.
If you think this your receptacle, then
Landlord I am, and shall so soundly prove,
As fines forgiven, you leese, free born our love.
Welcome our tenants Landlady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I do, my duty tenders it,
Sit then and frolic, for to my hearts liking,
Is this day consecrated, blessed the means,
That added to it, such prosperity,
While we sat sighing on the banks of bale,
Bliss kissed her cheek, and bids her joy, all hail.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: I such a storm as when the shower is past,
It drives destruction to thy soul,
Moral in faith, enigmas riddles so,
Music fal too, wife I will seat thee hear.
With pardon of thy betters.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: In yours she is the best and does command
Place and priority in the upper hand,
Besides, her beauty merits as the best,
To over shine stars, were they here possessed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well mocked my Lord.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: No, not a whit.
My judgment errs, if otherwise I censure it,
Sit sirs, for I, although invited, challenge here
Full flowing welcome, from his lips that lends,
As unto me, so much to all my friends,
And I begin in unto ye.

div1.stage: The Earle sits, and all do follow him.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: there is a cockerel tight,
That learns to crow from others, good my Earl,
If that my boldness may, challenge thy own,
Engage unto thy nobleness for ever,
I promise whose performance lightly gives,
Heart willingness to boot, cods me fill wine.
sp.stage: Filles two glasses, giues her one.
sp.l: Skink and carouse, wife charge this common shot
Level point blank, see who thy piercing eye,
Can mark to hit, if they be bullet free,
They scape the under daunt of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: They say he is cursed that by a cannon dies,
May I be blessed in such a destiny,
For of all other, I were only happy,
Being they eye-mark of so fair a shot.

sp.speaker: 1 Lor.
sp.l: Discharge bright beauty, and shoot home
Make me the man so happy.

sp.speaker: 2. Lor.
sp.p: aye, or me.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Or any, amongst so many, lives free choice
To one as principal, to each a voice.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then to the worthiest, to yourself my Lord.
By figure of the rest, it is understood,
By the kings nod, he greets his subjects freely,
Though his eye settle upon one.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Even so to me, I answer and acknowledge
Receipt of complement bestowed about
On every willing, and right welcome guest.
Pray ye all memories.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We do so, and he gives a duty.
To gratulate such seeming courtesy.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nurse, Iohn, unlooked for better welcome,
This is kindly visitation faith.

div1.stage: Enter Filbon, and Tutch, in blew like nurse, and Iohn ith Hospital.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Sir, it is my duty, and my beggared boldness
Makes me presume to trouble ye,
Knowing how you affect this ignorant,
I brought him to give welcome to your guests,
Hearing at London of this preparation.

sp.speaker: S VVil.
sp.l: At London, is it got so far abroad?
You see a niggards bounty how it spreads,
Like to a nine days wonder gentlemen:
And much the more, because it is seldom seen,
That covetous misers are so plentiful,
Faith, it is much in me.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: We find it so, sir William.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: now my suck-egg tell me, what is the news at London, you hear all.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.p:
That honest men want, and knaves get money, I have nothing, nurse has some, dogs are let
loose, and the bears undone, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: Came ye by foot Iohn, or by water?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: a horseback in the boat.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.p: Art no galled with riding, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: No, but weary with sitting, nurse shall sing a Geneua psalm, and bids these beggars welcome.

sp.speaker: S. William.
sp.p: How beggars, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: All the world is so, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: He says true, chide him not, we are no less.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Daughter welcome, Nurse all day, at night be your bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: my nurse, indeed my bed-fellow for ever,
My Filbon welcome, welcome as my husband,
My last, and for ever best beloved.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.l: Iames, To season this good meeting,
Take hand in hand with our fair wife and dance,
Gallants, my man can trick it with my Lady,
You shall see else, make not squeamish, to it,
It is my will, and what I will shall be.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Beseek ye sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Befoole ye sir wilt be, wife make not coy

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Since you command it, I am ready.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: I trow so, but I trust a potion pleads
By this time to true purpose, does it not?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I would not be so sped, for all the world,
It is done too late, it is past.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Good in the beginning, let her dance her last Who fronts me with a Cornucopian wreath, Were she a wife sprung from the race of kings, Such bitter breathing follows, now ye lamps, Of spotted Nemesis, burn blew, let the fall, Light on mischievous self, that dallied lately in our wretchedness, tell her sad sorrow, tombs and epitaphs tend her amazing obsequies, and then live free thou wronged soul from slanders cruelty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am not well sir, pray ye leave the dance.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.p: Not well, Iames be gone.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Sir, you shall pardon me, unless with her being not well.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Think you I will, what leave my country, sir. Upon a slight, a trifle, it is more dear to me.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: Wast not thy promise?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Pooh.

sp.speaker: S. William.
sp.p: Pooh.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Madam, lean on me, I will bring you to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pre-thee daughter, faith I am passing ill,
Your honour and the rest must bear with us,
It is nothing usual, a queasy fit.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: The mother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No, the husband.
Good faith I am not woman sick, though woman
But earnest ill, clogged at the very stomach with
A sudden calm, I fear me it is my death.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Nurse help to bring her to her closet, do.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: Excellent fit, supported by us too.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Plague on it, shall I be left alone, master make haste? But it is my deed, I am author of this shift, he is where he would be now, I am where I should be too, but not well backed, yes now I am.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Beseek ye pardon me.
Sir William, I am wronged, and to this company,
I make it known by coming of thy daughter:
Is my son made her endored husband, shall I
Suffer it, call you this courtesy it is simple craft?
Cloaked under thy denial, is this well to engraft with us unknown,
and so to join yonkers to heirs,
he is my only all, and married unto thy daughter?

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.p: Ha, Married? Nurse, how is it within?

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: She is very ill sir, and I fear.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: That your disguise is known, come juggle not, call you this Nurse? O thou dissembling boy.

sp.speaker: S. William.
sp.p: Are you married?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sir I must needs confess it, he is my husband, and the reason?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: No matter for the reason, I have done, God boy ye,
Cony-catched by a trick, and so persuaded, good.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: I am abused.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Yes questionless you are, I have all right.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: You have no wrong sir, I to affirm your word,
When I was woman, and from man I should, and now,
I trust my shape does challenge but your promise.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I played but Iohn come kiss me now says she, I am Tutch your quondam servant sir, thrust out to thrust them in, a lawful marriage is no mockery sir, I counterfeited welch, to join this construing English.

div1.stage: Enter Auditor and his sonne Foures.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: What at a gaze sir William? cannot be recalled.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: No, no, more mischief, nay come all together, welcome.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: Thank ye sir. My son returned, surrenders to your doom his life, for yours so lately lost, deputed in your daughter for she is dead sir, buried in the isle of Scillie.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Not amiss, what is the next Pagan? all the craft of this is known.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Sir had I too hearts to melt this frozen fear, would thaw with passion, the drops distilled from our tormented brain, witnessed by these sailers that interred her, knows how I parted with her when she died.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: Is mistress Mary dead?

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Well, shall I have Justice for her death?

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: Command it sir.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p:
To prison with him them, for she is murdered, Sir cause you knew your rapine and your theft, tied to your runaway legs that clog, you were uncertain of her portion and our love, therefore to rid that fear, you rid me thus of her (to me) most dear, my own, my only eldest of my
daughters, O.

sp.speaker: Audi.
sp.p: I will be his bale.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: Sir tell not me of bale, for my assurance pleads in his life, and he shall die.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: You have no president for that.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.l: Yes, remember Donningtons man, Grimes,
Who for an heir so stolen and married,
Was hanged, and the sergeant at arms
For assisting them, did loose his place,
If this were done, your theft will hardly scape.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: I thought of that indeed.

div1.stage: Enter Iames and Humill disguised still.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: Ha, by whom?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: By this fair counterfeit of husband, here is my witness, and the deputy in such a mischief.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: My wife is made away, poisoned here, and you that should be just are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.p: We follow, speak, explain this mystery.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Your wife sir.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Yes, supposed for dead, as risen from my grave, I came to More-clacke, but a little late, Even when the lying Priest did call her thine, She knew it, and devised with her glove, To repossess me of the house she challenged. so honoured, I slept with my own, but thought the contrary, you know what happened, that son that so betrayed his parents thus disguised, fearing ensuing mischief, wrought by you to have poisoned his dear mother, it was your biding, therefore murder, but the will of heaven bad otherwise, and yet she lives, wife what say you?

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: That all is so.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: And I affirm it true, my shape cast off does answer sir in few.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.l: Pretty in faith no marvel you forswore my bed,
When you had substance for a property,
Sir you must have your own, who can deny it?
And I must as the story runs be mum,
Fooled in myself by my own slights undone.
But what is this to my daughter, where is she?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Gouernor.
sp.p: Brother Vergir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Brother George from Scillie, what is the news?

sp.speaker: Gouernor.
sp.p: That your dear daughter dead and buried sir, by miracle was thus preserved, which at more leisure I shall manifest: pray ye forgive her fault, come there is some wanton blood left yet, says I, ye will I know, and wrongs past all remedy, the world must undergo.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: My Toures, the dead does live, I am thy wife, Mary.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Or her ghost, a shadow or a substance.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sister I will teach ye a medicine to make a shadow substance, lie with him tonight, as I will with my Filbon, and by the morning think but what is past, and you will reckon rightly you, he will hold you three to one my medicine's true.

sp.speaker: S. VVil.
sp.p: Methinks I have a tickling in my blood crosses all anger, malediction hence, hence, thou ill tempered Fear, this comical event seasons the true applause; since welcome is the word, in faith, I know not what to say, fain I would, and yet a lazy lagging apprehends with doubt, but well I know not what, in me, it lies to punish or to pardon, I will be general lie laughed at, once in sooth I will. I am a widower, gallants, and you meet at marriages, and funerals, so think it pray ye, I abridge all complement, bar all opponents, and resolve to favour you, you, you, and challenge from your lou, persuasion to this purpose, since our fate makes us the worlds fond Idiot, be it so youth, and your fortune was prodigious to it, and my best of spirit, binds up in this, all is but thankless merit.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: Then Epilogue am I,
Imagine all the world were in your house,
And hearing this report with wondering brain,
I thus excuse it, Gentlemen you see how fortune
Favours in extremity, if any botched up ill, have
Show of good, and is not in thee sequel understood,
Yet bear with all, as this old Knight has done,
Loosing a wife redoubled in a son, what you shall
Want in judgment, seeing this, think every
Act is subject to amiss, so to said, so done, will
Bring to true delight, hands meeting thus,
To sign this blessed night.
